qas.question: Who recorded the earliest records of migration?

answers.text: Homer and Aristotle, and in the Book of Job

qas.question: Which species of birds were recorded 3,000 years ago?
What is a major threat to migratory birds?

context: Historically, migration has been recorded as much as <a0_0>3,000 years ago<a0_0/> by Ancient Greek authors including <a1_0>Homer and Aristotle, and in the Book of Job<a1_0/>, for species such as <a3_0>storks, turtle doves, and swallows<a3_0/>. More recently, Johannes Leche began recording dates of arrivals of spring migrants in <a2_0>Finland<a2_0/> in 1749, and scientific studies have used techniques including bird ringing and satellite tracking. Threats to migratory birds have grown with <a4_0>habitat destruction<a4_0/> especially of stopover and wintering sites, as well as structures such as power lines and wind farms.
